Daman is a beautiful city in the Union territory of Daman and Diu. It is a historic city filled with Portuguese colonies, old churches, bungalows, and unspoiled allures of nature. The place is an emerging tourist destination and offers a memorable vacation to all. Visit the city during the vacation and pick from the best luxury hotels in Daman. 

Daman is a beautiful coastal city situated on the western coast of India and it is close to the borders of Maharashtra and Gujarat. It is a city, municipal council, and a district in the Indian Union Territory of Daman and Diu. A former Portuguese outpost and prior to that a Mughal controlled area, Daman is amongst those places in India that exhibit more of Portuguese culture than the Indian culture. The union territory remained under the reign of the Portuguese for over 400 years which significantly altered the culture, lifestyle, and eating habits of the place. Today, it is an emerging city and one of the prime commerce cities in the union territory. 
The old Portuguese past, East meets West cuisine, European style structures and buildings, and the unspoiled natural beauty of the place are widely known throughout the country, thus, putting the place on India tourism map. Today, the place is experiencing large influx of backpackers, particularly beach and culture enthusiasts, history buffs, and honeymooners, with a significant increase in the tourist count year after year. The good thing is that there is large enough number of hotels to accommodate the stay needs of the guests. The luxury hotels in Daman located in Nani Daman in particular are highly popular amongst the tourists as they offer the advantages of good connectivity and luxurious stay laden with modern amenities. 
The city is divided into two parts, Nani Daman and Moti Daman. Moti Daman or smaller Daman is basically the old part of the city with housing colonial bungalows, old streets, and markets. Whereas, Nani Daman or larger Daman is more modernized with housing commerce centres, hospitals, supermarkets, major offices, and modern residential areas. It is more busy and glamorize part of the place, whereas the old Daman is quiet and slow-moving. The literal meanings of these two names are opposite, however. It is quite interesting to experience the contrast between the two parts of one single city. However, both are full of major tourist attractions of Daman. 
It is said that Diogo de Melo, the famed Portuguese explorer and merchant arrived at the coast of Daman by chance. His actual route course was to Ormuz but was caught in a violent storm, resulting his boat directed towards the coast of Daman. Soon after his arrival, the place became a major settling point of the Portuguese. They built a large fort in 16th century to stop the invading Mughal armies, who had their sway over the lands before the arrival of Portuguese. Even today, the fort stands with most part of it preserved in the original form. Thus, making it one of the best preserved monuments in India. The fort today houses chief government offices and is a must-visit for every traveller who is in the city. 

Amongst the most popular sightseeing spots here include: Jampore Beach, Church of Bom Jesus, Pargola Garden, Paryatan Bhavan, Mirasol Water Park, Devka Beach, Kadaiya Lake Garden, Moti Daman, Somnath Mahadev Temple, House of Bockage, Jetty Garden, Collector Office, Chapel of Our Lady of Rosary, Daman Ganga Tourist Complex, St. Paul's Church, Nani Daman, and the small villages around the city.
